title_sort: laura curtis bullard to walt whitman, 3 may 1876
title: Laura Curtis Bullard to Walt Whitman, 3 May 1876
text: 35 East 39th StNew York City.May 3d 1876Mr Whitman,Dear Sir,My friend & yours Mr Joaquin Miller tells me that the best way to gratify a long-cherished wish of mine, ie, to have a complete edition of your poems, is to write to you directly for a copy of them—I therefore follow his advice—If you will write your own name on the fly leaf of the volumes, it will be a great favor to me & most-highly sent May 6 '76 see notes Jan'y 1889 appreciated—I was one of the earliest readers of your Leaves of Grass, that unique book, which so startled the many & so delighted the few— Permit me to congratulate you & to fel[feel] a little pride myself as an American that you have received such abundant recognition from the greatest men of our age both abroad & at home; & when I remember your work during our dreadful war, my heart as well as my pride is touched, & I cannot though a stranger to you, forbear presenting to the true man a nobler title even than that of the true poet, my profoundest respect & admiration—With sincere regard, yoursLaura Curtis BullardBullard Laura Curtis Bullard to Walt Whitman, 3 May 1876
